TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: uzai a vuluvulung a tsautsau a navaik a qemałup.
ozai a volovolong a caocao a navaik a qemaljop.
S.TRANSL: There was an old person who went hunting.

S.FORM: manu djemumak tua vetsiar a bulabulay.
mano djemomak toa veciar a bolabolay.
S.TRANSL: He found some beautiful flowers,

S.FORM: kiyayain tu sipavai tua marka ałak a vavayavayan.
kiyayain to sipavai toa marka aljak a vavayavayan.
S.TRANSL: and picked them to give to his daughters.

S.FORM: manu nua qatjuvi a vetsiar a kiniyaya.
mano noa qatjovi a veciar a kiniyaya.
S.TRANSL: The flowers he picked belonged to a snake.

S.FORM: qau mangtjez a qatjuvi.
qao mangtjez a qatjovi.
S.TRANSL: The snake came along.

S.FORM: "aku su kiyayain a ku vetsiar?
"ako so kiyayain a ko veciar?
S.TRANSL: “Why have you picked my flowers?

S.FORM: patsikelu.
pacikelo.
S.TRANSL: Put them back.

S.FORM: nu ini su patsikeli, ku katsi sun," ayain nua qatjuvi a vuluvulung.
no ini so pacikeli, ko kaci son," ayain noa qatjovi a volovolong.
S.TRANSL: If you don’t put them back, I’ll bite you,” said the snake to the old man.

S.FORM: qau patsikelen pasa tjua qapulu azua vetsiar.
qao pacikelen pasa tjoa qapolo azoa veciar.
S.TRANSL: So he put the flowers back to the roots.

S.FORM: łakua ini anga a patsikel.
ljakoa ini anga a pacikel.
S.TRANSL: But he couldn’t really put them back.

S.FORM: nu patsikelen, matjanitjani.
no pacikelen, matjanitjani.
S.TRANSL: When he put them back, they fell over.

S.FORM: kivadaq a qatjuvi: "uzai a nisun a ałak a vavayan, kemuda?"
kivadaq a qatjovi: "ozai a nison a aljak a vavayan, kemoda?"
S.TRANSL: The snake asked: “Have you got a daughter by any chance?”

S.FORM: "uzai," aya vuluvulung.
"ozai," aya volovolong.
S.TRANSL: “I have,” said the old man.

S.FORM: "nu maitazua, katsuu azua vetsiar, sa pavayan tua su ałak.
"no maitazoa, kacoo azoa veciar, sa pavayan toa so aljak.
S.TRANSL: “In that case, take the flowers and offer them to your children.

S.FORM: a tjenglay tazua vetsiar niaken anga a vaław.
a tjenglay tazoa veciar niaken anga a valjaw.
S.TRANSL: The one who likes the flowers will be my wife.

S.FORM: nu ini su papuvałavan tjanuaken, ku katsi sun," ayain a vuluvulung.
no ini so papovaljavan tjanoaken, ko kaci son," ayain a volovolong.
S.TRANSL: If you don’t give her to me as my wife, I’ll bite you,” he said to the old man.

S.FORM: qau katsuin nua vuluvulung azua vetsiar a pasa tjumaq; sa kivadaqi a ałak tu tima a tjenglay tazua vetsiar.
qao kacoin noa volovolong azoa veciar a pasa tjomaq; sa kivadaqi a aljak to tima a tjenglay tazoa veciar.
S.TRANSL: The old man took the flowers home, and asked his children which of them liked the flowers.

S.FORM: manu masengats a tjałavuluvulungan a vavayan.
mano masengac a tjaljavolovolongan a vavayan.
S.TRANSL: The oldest daughter didn’t like them at all.

S.FORM: qau qemaung azua vuluvulung.
qao qemaong azoa volovolong.
S.TRANSL: The old man cried.

S.FORM: "nu masengats mun, muri katsen aken nua qatjuvi," aya tjemumał tua marka ałak.
"no masengac mon, mori kacen aken noa qatjovi," aya tjemomalj toa marka aljak.
S.TRANSL: “If you all dislike them, I’ll be bitten by a snake,” he told his children.

S.FORM: qau penaula a sipułałakan a vavayan.
qao penaola a sipoljaljakan a vavayan.
S.TRANSL: His youngest daughter had pity on him.

S.FORM: "nu maitazua, idan azua vetsiar tjanuaken anga.
"no maitazoa, idan azoa veciar tjanoaken anga.
S.TRANSL: “In that case, give the flowers to me.

S.FORM: puvaław aken tua qatjuvi," aya.
povaljaw aken toa qatjovi," aya.
S.TRANSL: I’ll marry the snake,” she said.

S.FORM: sipavai nua vuluvulung.
sipavai noa volovolong.
S.TRANSL: So the old man gave them to her.

S.FORM: qau ka tjelutjeluan mangtjez a qatjuvi.
qao ka tjelotjeloan mangtjez a qatjovi.
S.TRANSL: On the third day the snake came.

S.FORM: "inu anga niaken a vaław?" aya a qatjuvi.
"ino anga niaken a valjaw?" aya a qatjovi.
S.TRANSL: “Where is my wife?” said the snake.

S.FORM: qau situlek nua kama.
qao sitolek noa kama.
S.TRANSL: The father pointed her out.

S.FORM: qau katsuin azua vavayan nua qatjuvi a sema tjua tapaw nimadju.
qao kacoin azoa vavayan noa qatjovi a sema tjoa tapaw nimadjo.
S.TRANSL: So the snake took the girl to his house.

S.FORM: manu vaivaik tiamadju a maḍusa i djalan.
mano vaivaik tiamadjo a madrosa i djalan.
S.TRANSL: The two of them were going along the path;

S.FORM: mintu mapavalit tu tsautsau azua qatjuvi tu vangsangsar.
minto mapavalit to caocao azoa qatjovi to vangsangsar.
S.TRANSL: and then the snake changed into a handsome man.

S.FORM: qau masalu aravats azua vavayan.
qao masalo aravac azoa vavayan.
S.TRANSL: The girl was very pleased.

S.FORM: djemałun tiamadju a maḍusa itjua tapaw nua qatjuvi.
djemaljon tiamadjo a madrosa itjoa tapaw noa qatjovi.
S.TRANSL: The two of them reached the snake’s house.

S.FORM: mintu bulay aravats azua tapaw.
minto bolay aravac azoa tapaw.
S.TRANSL: The house was very fine,

S.FORM: qaiłungan a patsatsikel.
qailjongan a pacacikel.
S.TRANSL: with mirrors all round.

S.FORM: nu kidjekets a lalangaw, seḍelas tua kinabulay nua tapaw.
no kidjekec a lalangaw, sedrelas toa kinabolay noa tapaw.
S.TRANSL: When flies tried to alight on it, they slipped because it was so fine.

S.FORM: qau azua qatjuvi ini pałetsasatsasavi azua vaław; marekutj tu maqunvułan.
qao azoa qatjovi ini paljecasacasavi azoa valjaw; marekotj to maqonvoljan.
S.TRANSL: The snake wouldn’t let his wife go outside. He was afraid of her (or the house) getting dirty.

S.FORM: manu vaik azua qatjuvi a sema kavuavuan.
mano vaik azoa qatjovi a sema kavoavoan.
S.TRANSL: The snake went off to the fields.

S.FORM: mangtjez azua kaka a tjałavuluvulungan a vavayan.
mangtjez azoa kaka a tjaljavolovolongan a vavayan.
S.TRANSL: His wife’s oldest sister came.

S.FORM: "aku bulay aravats a tsu a tapaw?
"ako bolay aravac a co a tapaw?
S.TRANSL: “Why is the house so fine?

S.FORM: kana tiaken a napuvaław," aya timadju a sałinga.
kana tiaken a napovaljaw," aya timadjo a saljinga.
S.TRANSL: If only I had married him,” she said in her longing for it.

S.FORM: qau "nangaq a ku qetsin tsu a vaław nua qatjuvi," aya timadju a kinemnem.
qao "nangaq a ko qecin co a valjaw noa qatjovi," aya timadjo a kinemnem.
S.TRANSL: “I must kill the snake’s wife,” she thought.

S.FORM: kiłavaran a kaka tjałavuluvulungan: "nangaq a kiqaiłungan itjen, tima tjabulay itjen."
kiljavaran a kaka tjaljavolovolongan: "nangaq a kiqailjongan itjen, tima tjabolay itjen."
S.TRANSL: The oldest sister said: “Let’s look in the mirror, to see who is more beautiful.”

S.FORM: qau kiqaiłungan tiamadju maḍusa.
qao kiqailjongan tiamadjo madrosa.
S.TRANSL: The two of them looked in the mirror,

S.FORM: manu tjabulay azua vaław nua qatjuvi.
mano tjabolay azoa valjaw noa qatjovi.
S.TRANSL: and the snake’s wife was more beautiful.

S.FORM: qau ini kasalu azua tjałavuluvulungan.
qao ini kasalo azoa tjaljavolovolongan.
S.TRANSL: The oldest sister was not convinced.

S.FORM: "djałepan tu namitung sun tua bulabulay, avan su sikabulay," aya.
"djaljepan to namitong son toa bolabolay, avan so sikabolay," aya.
S.TRANSL: “Of course it’s because you’ve got a fine robe on; that’s why you look nice,” she said.

S.FORM: qau pavalivaliten a itung, sa kiqaiłungan.
qao pavalivaliten a itong, sa kiqailjongan.
S.TRANSL: So they swopped robes and looked in the mirror.

S.FORM: łakua tjabulay angata azua vaław nua qatjuvi.
ljakoa tjabolay angata azoa valjaw noa qatjovi.
S.TRANSL: But the snake’s wife was definitely more beautiful.

S.FORM: kiłavaran anan uta azua tjavulung a vavayan: "nangaq a vaik itjen a kiqaiłungan a sema tjua laku," ayain azua vaław nua qatjuvi.
kiljavaran anan ota azoa tjavolong a vavayan: "nangaq a vaik itjen a kiqailjongan a sema tjoa lako," ayain azoa valjaw noa qatjovi.
S.TRANSL: The older said once more: “Let’s go to the well to look at our reflections,” she said to the snake’s wife.

S.FORM: qau vaik tiamadju a kiqaiłungan a sema tjua laku.
qao vaik tiamadjo a kiqailjongan a sema tjoa lako.
S.TRANSL: They went to the well to look at their reflections.

S.FORM: łakua tjabulay angata azua vaław nua qatjuvi.
ljakoa tjabolay angata azoa valjaw noa qatjovi.
S.TRANSL: But the snake’s wife was definitely more beautiful.

S.FORM: limutseng azua tjavulung a vavayan.
limoceng azoa tjavolong a vavayan.
S.TRANSL: The older girl was angry.

S.FORM: sizurung a pałetaladj tua laku.
sizorong a paljetaladj toa lako.
S.TRANSL: She pushed her sister into the well.

S.FORM: qau azua tjavulung a vavayan vaik anga kisan vaław tua qatjuvi.
qao azoa tjavolong a vavayan vaik anga kisan valjaw toa qatjovi.
S.TRANSL: And the older girl went to become the snake’s wife.

S.FORM: manu mangtjez a qatjuvi kasi kavuavuan, sa kiqenetji a vaław.
mano mangtjez a qatjovi kasi kavoavoan, sa kiqenetji a valjaw.
S.TRANSL: The snake came back from the fields and looked at his wife.

S.FORM: "aku sekulukulung anga a ku vaław?" aya timadju a kinemnem.
"ako sekolokolong anga a ko valjaw?" aya timadjo a kinemnem.
S.TRANSL: “Why has my wife become ugly?” he thought.

S.FORM: manu vaik timadju a tsałum a sema tjua laku.
mano vaik timadjo a caljom a sema tjoa lako.
S.TRANSL: And he went to the well to get water.

S.FORM: manu uzai a djurikuku: "hi hi hi hi. manu ku vaław, aya," aya zemaing.
mano ozai a djorikoko: "hi hi hi hi. mano ko valjaw, aya," aya zemaing.
S.TRANSL: There was a cockerel there. “Hee hee; ‘She’s my wife’ he thinks,” it crowed.

S.FORM: qau karimen azua djurikuku nua qatjuvi, sa katsu-i a tjumaq.
qao karimen azoa djorikoko noa qatjovi, sa kaco-i a tjomaq.
S.TRANSL: The snake looked for the cockerel and took it home.

S.FORM: qau manu vaik azua qatjuvi a sema kavuavuan.
qao mano vaik azoa qatjovi a sema kavoavoan.
S.TRANSL: And so the snake went off to the fields.

S.FORM: "pagału-i tsu a djurikuku.
"pagaljo-i co a djorikoko.
S.TRANSL: “Take care of this cockerel.

S.FORM: maya qemtsi," ayain a vaław.
maya qemci," ayain a valjaw.
S.TRANSL: Don’t kill it,” he said to his wife.

S.FORM: manu ḍemasi tua kasał.
mano dremasi toa kasalj.
S.TRANSL: She put some unhulled rice out to dry.

S.FORM: manu tsug a keman azua djurikuku.
mano cog a keman azoa djorikoko.
S.TRANSL: The cockerel kept eating it.

S.FORM: qau limutseng azua vaław; qetsin a djurikuku nazua vaław.
qao limoceng azoa valjaw; qecin a djorikoko nazoa valjaw.
S.TRANSL: The wife got angry, and she killed the cockerel.

S.FORM: mangtjez azua qatjuvi.
mangtjez azoa qatjovi.
S.TRANSL: The snake came back.

S.FORM: "inu anga ku djurikuku?" ayain a vaław.
"ino anga ko djorikoko?" ayain a valjaw.
S.TRANSL: “Where is my cockerel?” he said to his wife.

S.FORM: "keman aravats tua kasał.
"keman aravac toa kasalj.
S.TRANSL: “It kept eating the rice,

S.FORM: qau ku qetsin anga," aya kiłavaran tua vaław a uqałay.
qao ko qecin anga," aya kiljavaran toa valjaw a oqaljay.
S.TRANSL: so I killed it,” she said to her husband.

S.FORM: qau tsułuin anga azua djurikuku.
qao coljoin anga azoa djorikoko.
S.TRANSL: So the cockerel was butchered.

S.FORM: nu djemamay a uqałay, seti; nu djemamay a vavayan, tsuqelał.
no djemamay a oqaljay, seti; no djemamay a vavayan, coqelalj.
S.TRANSL: When they ate it as a side dish, the husband always got meat, and the wife got bones.

S.FORM: qau limutseng azua vavayan; siverits azua djamay.
qao limoceng azoa vavayan; siveric azoa djamay.
S.TRANSL: The wife was angry, and threw away the side dish.

S.FORM: mintu tsemuvuq a seray itjua vinritsan.
minto cemovoq a seray itjoa vinrican.
S.TRANSL: A pine tree sprouted at the place where the dish landed.

S.FORM: qau meqatsa azua seray, san sangelen.
qao meqaca azoa seray, san sangelen.
S.TRANSL: The pine tree grew tall, and the wood was used for a stool.

S.FORM: nu qemiladj a uqałay, minseg.
no qemiladj a oqaljay, minseg.
S.TRANSL: When the husband sat on it, it was steady;

S.FORM: nu qemiladj a vavayan, małeqałeqad.
no qemiladj a vavayan, maljeqaljeqad.
S.TRANSL: but when the wife sat on it, it wobbled.

S.FORM: limutseng azua vavayan.
limoceng azoa vavayan.
S.TRANSL: The wife was angry,

S.FORM: sipetsungu azua sangel.
sipecongo azoa sangel.
S.TRANSL: and used the stool for firewood.
